resources.text: Before you can do anything, you need to install Java's development version. Here is how you can do it:
resources.list:
• Navigate to the official download site on your computer.
  • Select the download for your operating system.
  • Extract and use the installer.
resources.boxed: Your IDE will look for Java based on the value of JAVA_HOME. If you are familiar with environmental variables, then simply set JAVA_HOME to the bin folder of your JDK install directory. If you need a full tutorial, follow this wikiHow link.
resources.text: Everything is ready to install an IDE now! In this case, I'll use Eclipse IDE, but feel free to use another IDE, if you have other preferences.

Navigate to the official Eclipse download page on your computer, then select the correct download for your operating system. Then unpack and run the installer! Installing other IDE's is a very similar process.

Java is a set of specifications for a software platform. It's purpose it to allow programmers to create a wide range of applications for a cross-platform environment. In this chapter and the next one we will take a look at what these terms mean, and how does the Java platform provides all this.
resources.boxed: Notice that the Java platform is more then just a programming language, however it does contain a language, the one which shares a name with the platform, Java. Several other languages such as Kotlin or Groovy also use the Java platform!
resources.text: The platform was created by James Gosling at Sun Microsystems, and now it's owned by the Oracle Corporation.
<u>Some important parts of the Java platform are:</u>
resources.list:
• The Java programming language
  • The Java Compiler (javac): compiles Java code into bytecode
  • The Java Virtual Machine (JVM): executes the compiled bytecode, runs Java programs
  • Class libraries: A large set of pre-written and compiled code, which can be used by any Java application.
resources.text: Notice that so far we only talked about a list of specifications for a software platform, and not an actual implementation! These specifications are public, and so anyone can create their own version of the platform, provided that they follow the rules of the specifications.

But since creating this takes an immense amount of work, Oracle also provides their implementation, called the Java Development Kit (JDK). This is the most widely used implementation, but others also exist, such as the OpenJDK. What you have just installed as "Java" was actually this, the JDK.

title.text: Cross platform and the WORA principle

resources.text: Java uses the Write once, Run anywhere (WORA) principle. This means that the programmer only needs to write and compile the source code once, after that, the compiled bytecode can be run with the Java Virtual Machine on any platform, such as Windows or Linux.
The above image illustrates how the WORA principle works in Java.
Lets see what happens when we decide to stop programming, and want to execute our code:
resources.list:
1. 1. - The source code is given to the compiler.
  2. 2. - The compiler checks if the code is valid, and if it is, compiles it into bytecode.
  3. 3. - The bytecode is given to the Java Virtual Machine, which executes it.
resources.text: Our IDE provides a run button for us, which will do this process for all our source files in the project. This way we don't have to call the javac and java commands from the command line.
Finally, lets take a look at the the programming language of the platform, Java. It is one of the most widely used language as of this day.

  • Cross-platform desktop applications
  • And many more...
